How does the hypothetical syllogism link p and r together in a conditional statement?

The hypothetical syllogism links p and r by stating that if q is true, then both p and r are true (1. p ⊃ qand if q is true, then r is true (2. q ⊃ r), thus concluding that if p is true, r must also be true (3. p ⊃ r).

A proof is a series of statements, starting with the premises and ending with the conclusion, where each additional statement after the premises is derived from some previous line(sof the proof using one of the valid forms of inference. We will practice this some more in the exercise at the end of this section. The next form of inference is called “hypothetical syllogism.” This is what ancient philosophers called “the chain argument” and it should be obvious why in a moment. Here is the form of the rule:  1. p ⊃ q 2. q ⊃ r 3. ∴ p ⊃ r  As you can see, the conclusion of this argument links p and r together in a conditional statement. We could continue adding conditionals such as “r ⊃ s” and “s ⊃ t” and the inferences would be just as valid.
